INTERNAL MEDICINE ASSOCIATES
OCHILTREE GENERAL HOSPITAL
History of present illness This is a 54-year-old white male here complaining persistent cough. He has had a dry cough for about two months. He was put on inhalers, but there was no improvement. The cough is worse at night, but also he has it during the day. He has no mucus production, no hemoptysis, no shortness of breath, and no wheezing. He is a nonsmoker. About a week ago, he was admitted to a local emergency room for chest pain. He was rushed to Ochiltree General because of ST-T wave abnormalities on his EKG. In retrospect, he has had these changes for many years, and anyway he had a cardiac catheterization, which showed mild obstruction of some of his coronary systems but no evidence of coronary artery syndrome. He did have cardiomyopathy with the ejection fraction of 35%. He was sent home on Toprol XL 50 mg QD, Lipitor 10 mg QD, lisinopril 10 mg, aspirin 325 mg once a day, and Avandia 2 mg once a day. Since returning home, the patient feels no chest pain or shortness of breath. No orthopnea or PND. He still has a dry cough.
